CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate shade trees and shrubbery - see Ohio R.C. 715.200
Assessments for tree planting and maintenance - see Ohio R.C. 727.011
Injuries or destruction - see GEN.OFF
541.06
 
CITY TREE COMMISSION
 
905.01 CREATION AND ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is created and established a City Beautification Committee/Tree
Commission for the City which shall consist of nine members, who may be
nonresidents, who shall be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the
Council. (Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.02 TERM OF OFFICE: COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The term of the nine persons (plus the Mayor and Superintendent of
Parks and Cemetery) to be appointed by the Mayor shall be three years, except
that the term of two of the members appointed to the first commission shall be
for only one year and the term of two members of the first commission shall be
for two years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any
members, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the
term.
   (b)   Members of the City Tree Commission shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.03 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   It shall be the responsibility of the City Tree Commission to study
investigate, counsel, develop and/or update annually and administer a written
plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, re-planting, removal, or
disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets, and in other public
areas. The plan will be presented annually to the City Council and upon their
acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive City tree
plan for the City. The Commission, when requested by the City Council shall
consider, investigate, make finding, report, and recommend upon any special
matter of question coming within the scope of its work. (Ord. 95-109. Passed
12-26-95.)
905.04 OFFICERS: RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The City Tree Commission shall choose its own officers, make its own rules
and regulations, and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the
members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. (Ord. 95-109. Passed
12-26-95.)
905.05 REVIEW BY CITY COUNCIL.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
905.05 was repealed by Ordinance 2004-74, passed September 7, 2004.)
TREE REGULATIONS
905.06 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)   "Park trees" means trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody
vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the
City, or to which the public has free access as a park.
   (b)   "Street trees" means trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody
vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets,
avenues, or ways within the City. (Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.07 STREET TREES SPECIES.
   The list attached to Ordinance 95-109, made a part thereof by reference,
constitutes the official street tree species for the City. No species other
than those included in the list may be planted as street trees without written
permission of the City Tree Commission. This list shall be reviewed and updated
annually by the Tree Commission. (Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.08 SPACING AND REQUIRED DISTANCES.
   (a)   The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three
species size classes referred to in the list referred to in Section
905.07, and no trees may be planted closer together than the following: small
trees, 30 feet: medium trees, 40 feet; large trees, 50 feet; except in special
plantings designed or approved by the Tree Commission.
 
   (b)   The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and
sidewalks will be in accordance with the three species size classes referred to
in the list referred to in Section
905.07, and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the
following: small trees, two feet; medium trees, three feet; and large trees,
four feet.
   (c)   No street tree shall be planted closer than 35 feet of any street
corner measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No
street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet to any fireplug. (Ord. 95-
109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.09 UTILITIES.
   No street trees other than those species referred to as small trees in the
list referred to in Section
905.07 may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility
wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer
line, distribution line, or other utility. (Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.10 PUBLIC TREE CARE.
   The City shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain, and remove trees,
plants, and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes,
squares, and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure public safety or to
preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The City
Tree Commission may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part
thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is
injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other
public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect, or other
pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent
property owners providing that the selection and location of the trees is in
accordance with Sections
905.07 to
905.09. (Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.11 TREE TOPPING PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or City
department to top any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property.
"Topping" is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than
three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to
remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by
storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other
obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from
this section at the determination of the City Tree Commission. (Ord. 95-109.
Passed 12-26-95.)
905.12 TREES OBSTRUCTING VISIBILITY.
   Every owner of any tree or shrubbery overhanging any street or right-of-way
within the City shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not
obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street
intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the
surface of the street or sidewalk. The owners shall remove all dead, diseased,
or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the
safety of the public. The City shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub
on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along
the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic
control device or sign. (Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.13 REMOVAL OF DEAD OR DISEASED TREES AND STUMPS.
    (a)   The City shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or
diseased trees on private property within the City, when such trees constitute
a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a
potential threat to other trees within the City. The City Tree Commission will
notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by said
owners at their own expense within 60 days after the date of service of notice.
In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the City
shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal on
the owners' property tax notice.
   (b)   All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed.
(Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.14 TREES IN NEW SUBDIVISIONS.
   The Tree Commission shall approve the tree plan for any new subdivisions.
(Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.15 ABUSE OR MUTILATION OF TREES.
   It shall be a violation of this chapter to abuse, destroy, or mutilate any
tree, shrub, or plant in a public tree lawn or any other public place, or to
attach or place any rope or wire (other than one used to support a young or
broken tree), sign, poster, handbill, or other thing to or on any tree growing
in a public place, or to allow any gaseous, liquid, or solid substance which is
harmful to such trees to come in contact with their roots or leaves.
(Ord. 95-109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.16 INTERFERENCE WITS TREE COMMISSION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay, or interfere with the
City Tree Commission, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the
planting, cultivation, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street
trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this chapter. (Ord. 95-
109. Passed 12-26-95.)
905.17 ARBORIST LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or
occupation of pruning, treating, or removing trees within the City without
first applying for and procuring a license. The license fee shall be $25.00
annually, in advance, provided however, that no license shall be required of
any public service endeavors. Before any license shall be issued, each
applicant shall first file evidence of possession of Worker's Compensation and
of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of $100,000 for bodily injury and
$100,000 property damage indemnifying the City or any person injured or damaged
resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described. (Ord. 95-109.
Passed 12-26-95.)
905.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. In addition, the person shall replace the tree with a size and
species recommended by the Tree Commission. Each tree affected by noncompliance
with this chapter shall constitute a separate violation. (Ord. 95-109. Passed
12-26-95.)
CHAPTER 907
Excavations
907.01   Excavation permit; application.
907.02   Laying pavement and pipes.
907.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Liability for damage - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
Barricades and warning devices - see GEN.OFF
521.03
 
907.01 EXCAVATION PERMIT; APPLICATION.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person, except a duly authorized agent of
the City, without first obtaining a permit, to dig or make any excavation of
any street right of way as defined by Section
 1106.01 of the Codified Ordinances. Application for the permit shall be made
in writing to the Zoning Department on blanks to be furnished by the
Department, signed by the owner of the property on account of which the
excavation is desired, and stating the lot and house numbers of the property,
the name of the owner, the names of the persons employed to make the
excavation, the length, width and depth of the proposed trench or excavation,
and the purpose for which the same is done. In case the application is made by
a company or corporation, the application shall be made by its president,
superintendent, or manager, and it shall contain the names of the persons under
whose supervision or direction the proposed excavation is to be made.
(Ord. 98-10. Passed 2-3-98.)
   (b)   The application shall contain an agreement that the property owner, in
the event the application is granted, will hold and save the City harmless from
any and all claims or suits for damages for negligent or improper conduct of
the proposed work, including the maintenance of proper barricades, danger
signals, and adequate and sufficient illuminated danger signals at night, in
conspicuous places for the protection of the public.
   (c)   The application shall also contain an agreement that the property
owner, in the event the application is granted, shall restore the street,
sidewalk, or other public grounds to a condition as good or better than the
street, sidewalk, or public grounds was prior to the excavation made under the
permit issued; and to insure that the street, sidewalk, or other public grounds
be properly restored, the owner, person, firm, or corporation making
application for permit shall post a bond with the Director of Public Service
and Safety with at least 2 sureties or a corporate surety company as sureties
thereon in the sum of not less than $500.00 conditioned to save the City
harmless from all damages arising from excavation, that the work be done in a
good and workmanlike manner, and that the conditions upon which the permit is
granted will be complied with to the satisfaction of the Director of Public
Service and Safety of the City.
   (d)   When an application under this chapter is granted, the application
therefore, the bond and the permit issued by the Director of Public Service and
Safety shall constitute an agreement by the applicant and the City upon payment
to the City by the applicant of a permit fee. The City Council shall, by
ordinance, establish a schedule of fees for all applications for all permits.
The schedule of fees shall be posted in the office of the Zoning Inspector and
may be altered or amended only by City Council. The fee shall accompany each
completed application. No action shall be taken on any application until such
time that all applicable fees are paid in full. (1979 Code 93.01)
907.02 LAYING PAVEMENT AND PIPES.
   No person shall construct or lay, or cause to be constructed or laid, within
any street or other public way of the City any street surfacing materials or
pavement, nor any sanitary or combined sewer line or water line, which might at
any time, present or future, become a part of the public streets or sewage or
water system of the City, unless the same be done under the express authority
of the Council of the City. (1979 Code 93.02)
907.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day's continued violation shall constitute a separate
offense.
CHAPTER 909
Building Numbering
909.01   Building numbering; conformity required.
909.02   Starting point.
909.03   Manner of numbering.
909.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.26
 
909.01 BUILDING NUMBERING; CONFORMITY REQUIRED.
   All business buildings and dwellings situated within the corporate limits
shall be numbered with legible figures by the owner in the manner and according
to the plan or system hereinafter prescribed and the rules and regulations
prescribed by the Director of Public Service and Safety to assure uniformity.
(1979 Code 93.10)
909.02 STARTING POINT.
   The initial or starting point shall be Main Street and Center Street,
respectively, for all streets running into or connecting with the lines, and
for all streets which do not connect with the aforesaid lines, the starting
points shall be with that end of the street which approximates nearest either
of the lines and running at right angles therewith. (1979 Code 93.11)
909.03 MANNER OF NUMBERING.
   The even numbers shall be put upon the east and north sides of the streets,
and the odd numbers upon the south and west sides, allowing approximately 20
feet for each number. In all basements occupied as business rooms, the half
number shall be used. Stairways leading to the upper stories of buildings shall
have the same number as the room on the street closest to the stairway, and the
letter "A" to designate second story, the letter "B" to designate third story,
and so on, affixed to such numbers. In case a stairway is located on the side
of a street, the stairway shall have the same number as the room to which it is
attached. On all stairways located on or near the dividing line, the stairways
shall bear the same number as the room having the lowest number. (1979 Code
93.12)
909.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision in this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
CHAPTER 911
Street Vacations
911.01   Petition for vacation of streets.
911.02   Fee.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Vacating streets - see Ohio R.C. 723.04 et seq.
 
911.01 PETITION FOR VACATION OF STREETS.
   All petitions addressed to Council praying for the vacation of street areas
shall be filed by the owner of the abutting property with the Clerk of the
Council. Petitions shall contain the street address of each of the petitioners,
along with the lot numbers of property owned by them and abutting the street
areas. The petition shall also disclose the reason for the proposed vacation,
and shall contain facts indicating that the vacation will not be detrimental to
the general interest. The petition shall further set forth the exact
description of the street area desired to be vacated, and shall contain a
waiver of notice and consent to the vacation. (1979 Code 93.20)
911.02 FEE.
   At the time of filing the petitions to vacate public streets or parts
thereof, there shall be paid to the Auditor the appropriate fee to cover the
cost of investigation, legal notices, and other expenses incidental to the
determination of the matter. The City Council shall, by ordinance, establish a
schedule of fees for all applications for all permits. The schedule of fees
shall be posted in the office of the Zoning Inspector. The fee shall accompany
each completed application. No action shall be taken on any application until
such time that all applicable fees are paid in full. (1979 Code 93.21)
CHAPTER 913
Sidewalk Construction and Repair
913.01   Abutting property owner responsibility.
913.02   Width and location.
913.03   Stone sidewalks.
913.04   Brick walks.
913.05   Cement sidewalks.
913.06   Sidewalk grade.
913.07   Ramped curbing for handicapped.
913.08   Permit for sidewalk Construction and repair.
913.09   Fee schedule.
913.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Construction and repair - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et seq.
Notice to construct or repair - see Ohio R.C. 729.03 et seq.
 
913.01 ABUTTING PROPERTY OWNER RESPONSIBILITY.
   The owner of each lot or parcel of land abutting upon any public street of
the City, whether the land is platted or not, shall construct good and
sufficient sidewalks along the street so far as the lot or parcel of land abuts
thereon, and shall do the necessary grading in accordance with the ordinances
upon the subject of sidewalks, whenever required so to do by resolution of the
Council. See Exhibit A, attached to original Ordinance 2000-92.
   All new construction of undeveloped lot(s) and/or underdeveloped lots of
record shall be required to have sidewalks on both sides of the street right of
way. Sidewalks shall be four feet wide with the line nearest the street right
of way to be one foot from said street right-of-way line. This includes both
residential and commercial buildings.
(Ord. 2000-92. Passed 11-21-00.)
913.02 WIDTH AND LOCATION.
   The width and location of sidewalks are established as follows: Upon all
streets where sidewalks have already been constructed, the sidewalks shall be
the same width as and conform to, as to location, other sidewalks on the same
street with an absolute minimum width of four feet, unless otherwise ordered by
the Director of Public Service and Safety; upon all streets having no
sidewalks, the width and location of new sidewalks shall be fixed by the
Director of Public Service and Safety. All sidewalks shall be constructed under
the supervision and subject to the approval of the Director of Public Service
and Safety. (1979 Code 93.26)
913.03 STONE SIDEWALKS.
   All stone sidewalks shall be of sawed or evenly dressed sandstone, not less
than 2 inches thick, and shall be laid with close joints on a bed of coarse
gravel, cinders, or broken stone not less than 4 inches deep. (1979 Code 93.27)
913.04 BRICK SIDEWALKS.
   Brick sidewalks shall be evenly laid with hard-burned brick, upon a bed of
broken stone not less than 6 inches deep, and with coarse sand, cinders, or
gravel on the stone.
(1979 Code 93.28)
913.05 CEMENT SIDEWALKS.
   All cement sidewalks constructed within the City shall be laid in sections
upon a good and substantial foundation, which shall be well tamped into place
before the concrete or cement is placed thereon. All sidewalks shall be at
least four inches thick except where crossing a driveway, in which case they
shall be at least six inches thick. All concrete sidewalks shall slope toward
the street at a rate of l/4-inch per one foot. All concrete sidewalks shall be
formed with wood or metal forms extending to the full depth of the concrete.
Premolded expansion joint fillers shall be installed between the sidewalks and
any fixed structure to the depth of the new concrete, and transversely at
intervals not to exceed 40 feet. There shall be no joints lengthwise in any
concrete sidewalks where the sidewalk does not exceed five feet in width. The
sidewalk shall be divided into blocks at intervals of four feet. All concrete
sidewalks shall have a nonskid surface.
(1979 Code 93.29)
913.06 SIDEWALK GRADE.
   All sidewalks must be laid on even grades, and made to join snugly with one
another and with the street crossings, and shall be upon the established
grades. No new sidewalks shall be constructed except under the grade to be
given by the Director of Public Service and Safety or his agent. All sidewalks
must be accepted by the Director of Public Service and Safety, and be put down
under his supervision. Whenever any sidewalk is repaired, it shall be done to
conform with the then existing grade and sidewalk. (1979 Code 93.30)
913.07 RAMPED CURBING FOR HANDICAPPED.
   All new curbs that are authorized by the Municipality, all existing curbs
which are part of any reconstruction and all sidewalk reconstruction, shall
have a ramp with non-slip surface built into the curb at each intersection or
pedestrian crosswalk so that the sidewalk and street blend to a common level.
These ramps shall be not less than 40 inches wide and shall, insofar as
feasible, be constructed in accordance with the standard drawing and
specifications for curb ramps of the State Department of Transportation.
(Ord. 99-2. Passed 1-5-99.)
913.08 PERMIT FOR SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR.
   No person shall construct or repair a sidewalk which runs along any public
street in the City without first obtaining a permit from the Director of Public
Service and Safety and complying with all reasonable requirements imposed by
the Director. Before a permit is granted, an application shall be made in
writing and shall be signed by the owner of the property on which the sidewalk
is to be constructed or repaired, stating the lot number, the name of the
person or persons employed to do the construction or repair work, the location
and specifications for the sidewalk to be constructed or repaired, the
estimated costs, and the estimated time for completion.
(1979 Code 93.32)
913.09 FEE SCHEDULE.
   The City Council shall, by ordinance, establish a schedule of fees for all
applications for all permits. The schedule of fees shall be posted in the
office of the Zoning Inspector. The fee shall accompany each completed
application. No action shall be taken on any application until such time that
all applicable fees are paid in full. (1979 Code 93.33)
913.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
CHAPTER 915
Curb Cuts
915.01   Permit for curb cut.
915.02   Bond.
915.03   Fee.
 
915.01 PERMIT FOR CURB CUT.
   (a)   No person shall cut, break, lower, remove, or otherwise change the
elevation or position of the curb or any portion thereof on any improved street
in the City without first having obtained a permit from the Zoning Department,
and complying with all reasonable requirements imposed by the Zoning Inspector.
Before permission is granted, the application shall be made in writing, signed
by the owner of the property on account of which the alteration or change of
curb is to be made, stating the lot number, the name of the person or persons
employed to make the alteration or change, the length and depth to be cut, or
the depth which the same is to be lowered, the manner in which the same is to
be altered or changed, and the purpose for which the same is done.
   (b)   If upon examination the Zoning Department is satisfied that the change
or alteration of the curb is necessary, will not be injurious to the improved
portion of the street, and will not unreasonably interfere with the public use
of the street, he may issue the permit and prescribe the conditions upon which
the work shall be done; provided that when residential property abuts the curb,
the permit shall not cover more than 20 lineal feet.
(Ord. 98-10. Passed 2-3-98; Ord. 2005-151. Passed 12-20-05.)
   (c)   If the alteration or change is to be made for the purpose of providing
for a driveway or approach, the person making the application shall be required
to improve that portion of the boulevard between the curb where lowered or
changed and the sidewalk by constructing therein a concrete base not less than
6 inches in depth and to the width that the curb is cut or lowered.
   (d)   If the alteration or change is to be made for the purpose of providing
for a driveway or approach to a business establishment, then the curb shall be
restored in the event the premises served by the driveway or approach is no
longer in use as a business establishment for a period of 6 months or more.
(1979 Code 93.40)
915.02 BOND.
   All persons to whom a permit is granted shall file a bond with the City
Auditor to the approval of the Director of Public Service and Safety, with at
least 2 sureties, in the sum of not less than $200.00, conditioned to indemnify
and save harmless the City from all damages arising from the change or
alteration in the curb, that the work be done in a good and workmanlike manner,
and that the conditions upon which the permit is granted will be complied with
to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Service and Safety, and that any
settlement in the curb or defect in the work done shall be made good at any
time within 2 years from the time of the completion of the work. (1979 Code
93.41)
915.03 FEE.
   At the time of issuance of any permit or license for cutting, lowering or
otherwise altering a curb, the Director of Public Service and Safety or his
representative shall collect from the applicant the appropriate permit fee. The
City Council shall, by ordinance, establish a schedule of fees for all
applications for all permits. The schedule of fees shall be posted in the
office of the Zoning Inspector. The fee shall accompany each completed
application. No action shall be taken on any application until such time that
all applicable fees are paid in full.
(1979 Code 93.42)
CHAPTER 917

917.01 DRAINAGE FROM BUILDINGS, CANOPIES, OR AWNINGS.
   No person, being the owner, or agent having the control or charged with the
management of any building within 10 feet of the line of any street, and having
a roof with a surface of more than 900 square feet, or a solid fixed canopy or
a solid fixed awning, regardless of the size of the canopy or awning, shall
cause or permit the building, awning, or canopy to be in such state of
disrepair as to cause or permit the water or ice resulting from the fall of
rain or snow to drain or fall, directly or indirectly, into a street; however,
it shall be lawful to cause water and ice to flow through proper spouts,
troughs, drains, or conduits to and into a sewer or gutter maintained by the
City in any street for drainage purposes. All spouts, troughs, drains, or
conduits shall connect with sewers or gutters in a manner as not to interfere
with other legitimate uses of the streets.
(1979 Code 93.51)
917.02 TREE LAWN MAINTENANCE.
   (a)   Every person owning property in the City abutting upon any macadamized
or improved street, in front of which and between which and the curbstone there
is a lawn, shall grade the lawn and set the same with grass, and shall keep the
same free from weeds and rubbish. In case of failure of any owner to comply
with the provisions of this section within 5 days after receiving, either by
himself or agent, notice from the Zoning Inspector so to grade and care for the
lawn, the grading shall be done by the Zoning Inspector, and the cost thereof
shall constitute a lien upon the premises so abutting on the lawn. The lien
shall be collected or enforced in the manner provided for the collection of
assessments of damages and expenses for making public improvements. (Ord. 96-
65. Passed 7-16-96.)
   (b)   (1)   Every owner, occupant or person having charge of any building,
lot or land abutting upon any street right of way or any public highway right
of way in the City, shall grade the tree lawn or curb strip and set the same
with grass, and shall keep the entire width of the tree lawn, curb strip, or
public property from the street line or curb to the lot line, in good repair
and free from grass exceeding a height of twelve inches.
      (2)   The City shall be responsible for lawn maintenance of railroad
underpass areas (Mid-Block, Center St., and Lytle St.).
      (3)   Nothing in this subsection shall prohibit the planting of landscape
plant materials or approved trees.
      (4)   Enforcement of this subsection shall be the responsibility of the
Zoning Inspector. (Ord. 99-73. Passed 8-3-99.)
917.03 CLEANING SIDEWALKS.
   (a)   When the Council declares by resolution that a certain specified
sidewalk shall be cleaned so as to be free from weeds, grass, dirt, or any
other objectionable substance, it shall then be the duty of the Clerk of the
Council to cause notice of the passage of the resolution to be served upon the
owner of each parcel of land abutting upon the sidewalk ordered cleaned. The
notice shall be given in the same manner as is provided for service of notice
to construct sidewalks.
   (b)   If the sidewalks are not cleaned within 5 days after the service of
notice or completion of the publication, the Zoning Inspector shall have the
same done at the expense of the owner, and report the costs thereof to the
owner and to the Council. The cost of cleaning shall constitute a lien upon the
property abutting upon the sidewalk from the date the same is so reported, and
shall be paid by the owner to the Treasurer of the City. If the costs of
cleaning are not paid within 10 days from the time the same has been recorded,
the Zoning Inspector shall certify the same, together with a penalty of 5%
thereon, to the County Auditor, who shall place the same on the tax duplicate,
and collect the costs and penalties in the same manner as other taxes are
collected. (Ord. 96-66. Passed 7-16-96.)
917.04 PERMANENT STRUCTURE ON SIDEWALKS.
   No person shall erect, cause to be erected, or permit to remain standing any
house, building, wall, stairs, fence, portico, wooden awning, step, cellar
door, or other permanent structure, in the manner that the same or any part
thereof shall stand or project into any street, street right of way, sidewalk,
or public ground of the City without first having obtained a permit from the
Zoning Inspector complying with all reasonable requirements imposed by the
Zoning Inspector.
   Before the permit is granted, an application shall be made in writing,
signed by the owner of the property on account of which the structure is to be
erected, with a statement by the owner that the structure will in all respects
comply with the plans and specifications approved by the Zoning Inspector.
(Ord. 96-67. Passed 7-16-96.)
917.05 USE OF SCAFFOLDING AND OTHER BUILDING MATERIALS.
   (a)   (1)   No person shall place, construct, or cause to be placed upon any
street, sidewalk, or public ground any scaffolding, brick, stone, line, timber,
lumber, planks, boards, or other building material, unless authorized by the
Director of Public Service and Safety, except persons engaged in erecting or
repairing some building structure or other improvement.
      (2)   Provided that proper arrangements are made if the occupancy
involves the use of parking-metered space, persons erecting or repairing
structures may use and occupy with such material 1/2 of the sidewalk, and 1/
3 of the street in front of and adjoining the premises upon which the building,
structure, or improvement is in process of erection or repair, for a period not
exceeding 4 months, unless sooner directed to remove the same. The Director of
Public Service and Safety may, in case of necessity, by a written permit,
extend the time of occupancy from time to time, not exceeding one month at any
one time.
   (b)   No person having the privilege of using and occupying any street,
sidewalk, or public area shall occupy the same for working up or preparing
materials which might be worked up or prepared for the structure or building
elsewhere, and all material shall be so used and placed so as not to interfere
with the free use of the sidewalk and street not so occupied, or with the free
passage of the water in the gutters, and all persons so occupying the street,
sidewalk, or public area shall at the expiration of the 4 months or of the time
to which the same may be extended, or upon being notified so to do at any time
by the Director of Public Service and Safety, remove the materials and all dirt
and rubbish caused thereby. (1979 Code 93.59)
917.06 UNLOADING ON STREET OR SIDEWALK.
   No person shall unload any heavy material in the streets by throwing or
letting the same fall upon the pavement of any street, sidewalk, or other
public way, without first placing some sufficient protection over the pavement.
(1979 Code 93.60)
917.07 ALTERING GRADES; REMOVING MARKERS.
   (a)   No person shall in any way change, alter or interfere with the line,
grade, width or form of any street right of way as defined by Section
1106.01 of the Codified Ordinances, or any mark, stakes, or monuments thereof,
or cause or assist the same to be done without filing an application with and
receiving a permit from the Zoning Department.
   (b)   The process for approval of construction of improved parking areas
(see Section
351.03(s)) is:
      (1)   File an application with the Zoning Department. A fee as
established by Council (see fee Ordinance No. 94-11 amended) shall accompany
each completed application;
      (2)   After administrative review, the application shall be submitted
with recommendation by the Zoning Department to Council;
      (3)   Council votes on the application by resolution;
      (4)   If Council passes the resolution approving the application, the
Zoning Department will then issue a permit to the applicant.
   The main criteria that the applicant must show for construction and/or
alteration in this subsection is that a hardship exists and that the condition
was not created as a result of the applicant’s action. Further, the change must
not endanger public safety, create a nuisance, or inhibit drainage. (Ord. 98-
10. Passed 2-3-98.)
917.08 PROPERTY OWNERS TO BE RESPONSIBLE FOR UNIMPROVED STREETS ADJOINING THEIR
PROPERTY.
   Adjoining property owners are to be responsible for the unimproved alleys or
streets that are adjoining their residential or commercial properties as far as
grass, weeds, man-made obstructions and junk, garbage, refuse and other similar
materials.
(Ord. 98-59. Passed 7-7-98.)
917.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate
offense. (1979 Code 93.99)

933.01 SUBSTANCES IN RESERVOIR OR WATER BASIN.
   No person shall throw, cast, or deposit any article or substance whatsoever
into any reservoir, filter basin, or clear water basin belonging to or that may
be a part of the waterworks of the City. (1979 Code 51.01)
933.02 POLLUTING WATER SUPPLY; SWIMMING.
   No person shall pollute the water supply of the City by depositing therein
any dead animals, refuse; or any filthy, putrid, offensive, or unhealthy
substance or matter, or by swimming or bathing therein. (1979 Code 51.02)
933.03 FIRE HYDRANTS.
   (a)   No person not duly authorized shall turn on or cause the flow of water
from any hydrant, valve, plug, or other fixture of the waterworks.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(1979 Code 51.03)
933.04 WATER-SUPPLY EMERGENCIES.
   (a)   When, in the judgment of the Mayor, hazardous conditions have
developed or appear likely to develop due to drought or other water-supply
interruptions to the City, the Mayor may at his discretion declare a water-
supply emergency.
   (b)   The effective time of a water-supply emergency shall be stated in the
declaration.
   (c)   Whenever a water-supply emergency is so declared, the Mayor shall, as
soon as possible thereafter, furnish a copy of such declaration to the local
news media and the Police Department.
   (d)   A water-supply emergency shall continue until a termination
announcement is made by the Mayor.
   (e)   After a water-supply emergency has been formally declared, no person
shall, during the period of the emergency, utilize water supplied by the
municipal system for filling or maintaining swimming pools, washing vehicles,
washing structures or other objects out-of-doors, water lawns, trees, shrubs or
other growing vegetation, or otherwise use water outside of homes or businesses
for any purpose except for human consumption, or in the event of a fire- or
life-threatening emergency. The Mayor may modify the restrictions set forth in
this division if, in his sole judgment, conditions so warrant, by indicating
said modifications in his declaration.
   (f)   When in the judgment of the Mayor conditions so warrant, restrictions
within homes or businesses in addition to those identified in division (e)
above may be imposed by the Mayor in his declaration of water-supply emergency,
thereby restricting water usage to health, sanitation, and emergency needs
only. No person shall violate such additional restrictions within homes or
businesses during the period of such water-supply emergency. (1979 Code 51.04)
933.05 BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE.
   If, in the judgment of the Superintendent of Utilities, an approved backflow
prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water system, the
Superintendent of Utilities will give notice to the water consumer to install
the approved device immediately. The water consumer shall, at his own expense,
install the approved device at a location and in a manner approved by the
Superintendent of Utilities and shall have inspections and test made of the
approved device as required by the Superintendent of Utilities. (1979 Code
51.10)
933.06 CONNECTION TO OTHER WATER SUPPLY PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm, or corporation shall establish or permit to be established,
or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private,
auxiliary, or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply
of the City may enter the supply or distributing system of the Municipality,
unless the private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply and the method of
connection and use of the supply shall have been approved by the Superintendent
of Utilities of the City and by the State Environmental Protection Agency.
(1979 Code 51.11)
933.07 SURVEYS AND INVESTIGATIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Superintendent of Utilities to cause surveys and
investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served by the
public water supply where actual or potential hazards to the public water
supply may exist. These surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of
public record and shall be repeated as often as the Superintendent of Utilities
shall deem necessary. (1979 Code 51.12)
933.08 RIGHT OF ENTRY; OWNER TO PROVIDE INFORMATION.
   The Superintendent of Utilities of the City or his or the City's duly
authorized representative shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time
any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distributing
system of the City for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems
thereof. On demand the owner, lessees, or occupants of any property so served
shall furnish to the Superintendent of Utilities any information which he may
request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on the property.
The refusal of this information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of
the Superintendent of Utilities, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper
connections as provided in this chapter.
(1979 Code 51.13)
933.09 DISCONTINUANCE OF WATER SERVICE FOR VIOLATION OF REGULATIONS.
   The Superintendent of Utilities of the City is authorized and directed to
discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service
to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this
chapter is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he
may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water
supply distribution mains. Water service to the property shall not be restored
until the conditions shall have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with
the provisions of this chapter. (1979 Code 51.14)
933.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day upon which a violation occurs shall be considered a
separate offense.
(1979 Code 51.99)

937.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   Purpose and Policy
   This chapter sets forth uniform requirements for users of the Publicly Owned
Treatment Works (POTW) for the City of Fostoria and enables the City to comply
with all applicable State and Federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33
United States Code [U.S.C.] section 1251 et seq.) and the General Pretreatment
Regulations (Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations [CFR] Part 403). The
objectives of this ordinance are:
   (a)   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that will
interfere with its operation;
   (b)   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that will pass
through the POTW, inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or otherwise be
incompatible with the POTW;
   (c)   To protect both POTW personnel who may be affected by wastewater and
sludge in the course of their employment and the general public;
   (d)   To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of
operation, maintenance, and improvement of the sewer system and the POTW; and
   (e)   To enable the City to comply with its National Pollutant Discharge
Elimination System permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements, and
any other Federal or State laws to which the POTW is subject.
   This chapter shall apply to all users of the POTW. The ordinance authorizes
the issuance of individual wastewater discharge permits; provides for
monitoring, compliance, and enforcement activities; establishes administrative
review procedures; requires user reporting; and provides for the setting of
fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program
established herein. (Ord. 2014-09. Passed 3-4-14.)
937.02 ADMINISTRATION.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety (Director) shall administer,
implement, and enforce the provisions of this ordinance except as otherwise
provided herein. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the Director may
be delegated to a duly authorized representative.
(Ord. 2014-09. Passed 3-4-14.)
937.03 ABBREVIATIONS.
   The following abbreviations, when used in this chapter, shall have the

   BOD   -   Biochemical Oxygen Demand
   BMP   -   Best Management Practice
   BMR   -   Baseline Monitoring Report

   NPDES -   National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System

   POTW -   Publicly Owned Treatment Works
   RCRA -   Resource Conservation and Recovery Act
   SIU   -   Significant Industrial User
